properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 7:30 p.m. MDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-06-25T04:29:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-25T01:30:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2232968296.2020
Area: Cypress Co. near Tide Lake, S.A. 2 near Iddesleigh and Dinosaur Prov. Park, S.A. 2 near Jenner and Atlee, S.A. 2 near Buffalo and Cavendish, Cypress Co. near CFB Suffield

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hot and humid for inland areas of Nova Scotia. Time span: tonight and Thursday. Minimum temperatures tonight: near 18 Celsius. Maximum temperature Thursday: near 29 degrees Celsius parts of northern region and the Southwestern Shore (Humidex 35). Locations: Annapolis Valley through parts of northern Nova Scotia, Southwestern Shore. Remarks: warm temperatures and humid conditions are expected to continue into Thursday over much of Nova Scotia, and may also continue into the early part of the weekend in Pictou and Antigonish. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-25T17:25:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-25T01:26:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4209607269.2020
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Pictou County, Antigonish County

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. A trough of low pressure tracking across central Saskatchewan is triggering scattered thunderstorms this evening. Some of these thunderstorms could be severe. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 39 are expected for the next 2 days. Hot and humid conditions continuing in the east on Thursday. Time span: tonight and Thursday. Minimum temperature tonight: 18 degrees Celsius Maximum temperatures Thursday: 30 degrees Celsius ( Humidex 36) Locations: eastern New Brunswick. Remarks: Hot and humid conditions will continue tonight and Thursday for eastern New Brunswick. A break in the heat will be coming on Friday. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-25T17:19:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-25T01:20:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1961159868.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 33 are expected for the next 3 days. Warm and humid conditions continue. Time span: tonight and Thursday. Minimum temperature tonight: near 18 degrees Celsius. Maximum temperature Thursday: near 28 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34). Locations: Prince Edward Island Remarks: Warm weather is expected to continue into Thursday with temperatures near 28 degrees in the afternoon, especially away from the coast. Temperatures are expected to remain below warning criteria on Friday. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. Maximum rainfall rates: locally 20 to 30 mm per hour in thunderstorms. Maximum wind gusts: near 80 km per hour in thunderstorms. Locations: northwestern New Brunswick. Time span: late this evening into the early overnight hours. Remarks: There remains as slight risk for severe thunderstorms to develop over eastern Maine this evening and move into northwestern parts of New Brunswick into the early overnight period. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-25T05:59:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T23:22:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0570351704.2020
Area: Woodstock and Carleton County, Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 5:26 p.m. CST, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. This line of severe thunderstorms is currently located from Buchanan to Yorkton and is tracking northeast at 30 km/h. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-06-25T02:09:14-00:00
